de.esoco.lib.json

Class JsonArray

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      • java.util.AbstractList<E>
        • java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object>
          • de.esoco.lib.json.JsonArray
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    JsonSerializable<JsonArray>, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Object>, java.util.Collection<java.lang.Object>, java.util.List<java.lang.Object>, java.util.RandomAccess

    public class JsonArray
extends java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object>
implements JsonSerializable<JsonArray>
    An extension of ArrayList that also implements JsonSerializable so that it can be used directly in JSON expressions. The implementation does not validate the datatype of added elements. It is the responsibility of the application to ensure that only valid JSON values are contained.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • of

        public static JsonArray of(java.lang.Object... rElements)
        Factory method to create a new array from initial elements. The returned instance is mutable.
        Parameters:
        rElements - The initial elements of the array
        Returns:
        The new JSON array

      • appendTo

        public void appendTo(JsonBuilder rBuilder)
        Appends this instance to a JSON builder. This method needs to be implemented to allow the serialization of hierarchical structures. To simply serialize a (root-level) object use the default method JsonSerializable.toJson() instead.
        Specified by:
        appendTo in interface JsonSerializable<JsonArray>
        Parameters:
        rBuilder - The JsonBuilder to append this instance to

      • fromJson

        public JsonArray fromJson(java.lang.String sJson)
        Parses data from a JSON string and returns the resulting instance. Invocations should always work with the returned instance as immutable implementations will return a new instance.

        All implementing types should provide a no-argument constructor that does as few initialization as possible. This applies especially to immutable types that will only be created to invoke this method, which will then create and fill a new instance.

        Specified by:
        fromJson in interface JsonSerializable<JsonArray>
        Parameters:
        sJson - The JSON string to parse
        Returns:
        This instance so that it can be directly used after de-serialization
